A typical London set. Early advance of the kingside pawns to concentrate the game on the black's castling.
As always, an unexpected move. My dsb is self.trapped, but it holds a cramped position for black.

I thought b4, but then there is a solid attack from black on the black diagonal, after Na5, QXe4, c3, and the black queen can go to a5...
Dangerous, but the key of the position is to have the kingside free for the rooks, in sight of a pawnstorm.
Preventing b4, I won't play anyway.
...and the pawn is won, but I will exchange my best bishop. Hmmm...
QxQ would have been bad for black, but... this one... well, maybe...
I am not in a hurry to take the pawn. It is better to prevent b5, that can gives black some countergame.

Now, c6 is not so important, because the queen is far from the black diagonal. 
Black expects me to take the pawn, exchange the bishop and play b5. 
I decided that the game would have been really boring this way, and I launched a challenge.

!?
I am crazy, no doubt.
And black takes the bite. Now, my only advantage is positional. It won't be clear in few moves.

Maybe g6 was better, just to prevent what follows, but if so, h5, inmediately.
